quoteTime: about eight o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , to the porter of the Hotel San-Real.

quoteFirst: This was
quoteLast: , and with colours flying and bands playing merrily in the sunshine, this huge human rectangle marched in a north-easterly direction, past two great empty kraals and a vast green tumulus that marks the grave of King Panda, the father of Cetewayo, who is seated therein, buried in a partly upright position, according to Zulu custom.

quoteFirst: Most of our horses used to go from Oran to Mascara in a single day, and could repeat the journey for two or three consecutive days. On one occasion we started from Saïda
quoteLast: to fall upon the Arbâa, who were encamped at Aaïn-Toukria, among the Oulad-Aïad near Taza, and we came up with them at break of day.
title: The Horses of the Sahara and the Manners of the Desert
author: Daumas, E.‏ (Eugène), 1803-1871; Hutton, James, 1818-1893 [Translator]

title: A History of the Coldstream Guards, from 1815 to 1895

quoteFirst: His Excellency and his retinue this day pass the _Danube_, between _Tutracán_ and the mouth of the _Argisch_,
quoteLast: , at a passage about a mile broad. Upon landing, his Excellency was complimented from the Prince of _Valachia_ by his cousin german Count _Tomáso Cantacuzéno_, and was received by a guard of fifty men, and two coaches of six.
title: Travels in Turkey and back to England
author: Chishull, Edmund, 1671-1733; Mead, Richard, 1673-1754 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: "At Jonesboro we learned from the station employees that another train would be due from Richmond
quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: . Thirteen miles above that place the railroad crossed the Watauga River, where there was a rebel blockhouse or fort protected by artillery, and which we learned was garrisoned. Our only hope of getting to Bristol was to capture the incoming train and rush our own train unawares into the fort and take the garrison by surprise.
title: War Stories for my Grandchildren
author: Foster, John Watson, 1836-1917

quoteFirst: Colonel W. W. Henry started for Vermont this morning; most of the officers of the regiment went to the cars to see him off; commenced raining
quoteLast: ; didn't rain long; men very busy on their cabins; got a Washington Chronicle to-night; good news from Generals Sherman and Thomas, the latter having captured fifty eight guns and five thousand prisoners.
title: Personal Recollections and Civil War Diary, 1864
author: Abbott, Lemuel Abijah, 1842-1911

quoteFirst: Pa says there ought to be a law that babies should arrive on the regular day trains, and not wait for the midnight express. Well, Pa he got asleep, and he slept till
quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , and the blinds were closed, and it was dark in his room, and I had to wait for my breakfast till I was hungry as a wolf, and the girl told me to wake Pa up, so I went up stairs, and I don't know what made me think of it, but I had some of this powder they make red fire with in the theatre, that me and my chum had the 4th of July, and I put it in a washdish in the bath-room, and I touched it off and hollered fire.
title:
Peck's Bad Boy and His Pa
1883
author: Peck, George W. (George Wilbur), 1840-1916; Smith, Gean, 1851-1928 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The ground was then patrolled, the arms of the dead Zulus collected, and the position strengthened as far as possible. About seven a.m. a large body of the enemy was again seen on the hill to the south-west, and a friendly Kaffir, who had come in shortly before, was sent to Helpmakaar to ask for assistance. However,
quoteLast: the British 3rd column began to appear, whereupon the enemy, who had been again advancing, fell back as the troops advanced, and Rorke's Drift Post had been saved.
title: The Story of the Zulu Campaign
author: Ashe, Waller, 1840-1893; Wyatt-Edgell, Edmund Verney, 1845-1879

quoteFirst: Will you come up here on the sixth of September and stay until the sixteenth? It would give us all the greatest pleasure. There is a train leaving Broadway Station at
quoteLast: which will get you to Dustville Junction at 5 P.M. and here in time for supper.

quoteFirst: "We went ashore on 'A' beach
quoteLast: and walked up to Stopford's Headquarters, as he had gone ashore the night before. They all seemed a very lifeless crew, with but little knowledge of the general situation and no spirit in them. We made our way on across some rocky scrubby country towards Brigade Headquarters; fairly heavy rifle fire was going on, and after about two miles bullets began to ping unpleasantly all round us.
title: Gallipoli Diary, Volume 2
author: Hamilton, Ian, 1853-1947

quoteFirst: It was
quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: when they came in sight of the town.  The village of Trenton then contained about one hundred houses, mostly frame, scattered along both sides of two long streets, and chiefly located on the west bank of the Assunpink, which here bent sharply to the north before it flowed into the Delaware.
title: For Love of Country: A Story of Land and Sea in the Days of the Revolution
author: Brady, Cyrus Townsend, 1861-1920

quoteFirst: “Fantômas left, I suppose,
quoteLast: , quite early anyway; but his match was not lit till two or three o’clock in the afternoon. You needn’t be surprised, Fandor, the trick is quite elementary! Look there, on the carpet, near the wardrobe; you see those little shards of glass? the fragments of a burning-glass! The tinder was set alight by means of that lens, scientifically adjusted for the precise moment when the sun had reached the altitude chosen by Fantômas.
title: The long arm of Fantômas
author: Souvestre, Pierre, 1874-1914; Allain, Marcel, 1885-1969; Allinson, A. R. (Alfred Richard), 1852-1929 [Translator]

quoteFirst: He was called "Père Noël" (Father Christmas) because of his big beard. He was seventy-five years old. It was the 29th of August,

quoteFirst: The “Albatross” began to come under control again. And, what was a great comfort, had again entered the lighted regions of the globe; and the day reappeared
quoteTime: about eight o’clock in the morning
title: Robur the Conqueror
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905
